metadata.title: Labor for the Picking: The New Deal in the South

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change
relevance.relevance: The study examines the displacement of sharetenants due to the introduction of wage laborers and mechanization in the South during the Great Depression, highlighting the impact of AAA policies and economic conditions on labor markets.

design.sample_characteristics: The study focuses on the Delta region, covering 23 counties in Mississippi, Arkansas, and Louisiana.
design.geographical_focus: Delta region in the Southern United States

dependent_variables.displaced: The study discusses the displacement of sharetenants as landlords shifted to wage labor and mechanization.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Displaced tenants faced unemployment or became part of the wage labor market.

qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study provides a detailed narrative of how AAA policies and economic conditions led to the displacement of sharetenants and the adoption of mechanization in the South.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The study is set during the Great Depression, a period of economic hardship and restructuring.
historical_context.institutional_context: The AAA policies aimed to increase farm income and reduce cotton production, impacting labor markets and land tenure.

outcomes.main_findings: The study finds that AAA policies and economic conditions during the Great Depression led to significant displacement of sharetenants, facilitating the shift to wage labor and mechanization.
outcomes.conclusions: The New Deal policies inadvertently altered the labor market structure in the Cotton South, favoring landlords and leading to tenant displacement.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The displacement had lasting effects on the social and economic structure of the Cotton South, with implications for labor markets and mechanization.
